Fellowships
Three Johns Hopkins University seniors were named this
week by the Woodrow Wilson
National Fellowship Foundation
as scholarship recipients for
1962-63.
Melvin Goodman and David
Whip 'of Baltimore, and Roy
Feldman of Hempstead, N. Y.
have been awarded the one-year
graduate fellowships. Each fellowship covers a full year's tuition and fees at a graduate
school of the fellow's choice and
a living allowance of $1,500.
Goodman, a history major, is
a graduate of Forest Park High
School. He is the son of Mr. and
Mrs. Harry W. Goodman of 3840
Boarman Ave.
Political Economy
Whip, a City College graduate,
is studying political economy. He
is the son of Mr. and Mrs. H.R.
Whip of 3810 Kimble Rd.

verbal behavior, learning and
thinking. He will receive a combined M.A. and B.A. in June.

James E. Feldman of Hempstead,
and a graduate of Hempstead
High School.

attending graduate school.

familiarized himself with riot tactics in the East

educational experiences was his stay at one of
the Army's disciplinary barracks — as parole
officer.

anyone without the colonel's easy-going outlook,
but Biggy and his master are well qualified for
a rather trying job. The perfect dormitory
counsellor should be a friendly participant in
student affairs and a mature companion for
"his men." Col. Serena and Biggy, after only

and water fights, we reprint the following editorial from
the NEWS-LETTER issue of May 12, 1961:
Spring riots have become a pretty standard and
perennial affair on this and most other college campuses.
Often, as recently seen at Harvard University, they reach
tremendous proportions involving thousands of seething
students on the rampage.
Generally, campus disorders of this type are not
taken seriously on this campus. Rioting is regarded by
many as a good natured, harmless method for young,
unmarried males, immured for a long, cold winter, to
"let off some steam."
We have always looked benignly on this "fun" and
tacitly encouraged some of it. However, one must recognize the possible dangers involved in mob action. It
takes very little to convert a vigorous water fight into
a dangerously mobile anti courageous mob. Fortunately
in recent years riots at Hopkins have not resulted in any
serious injury or destruction, but the potential for such
is great. This is especially true when the inevitable cry
"To Charles Street!" rings out anti the crowd spills off
the campus.
We do not urge complete suppression of boisterous
activities. But we do urge the caution anti forethought
characteristic of the so-called "Hopkins Gentleman."

many as a good natured, harmless method for young,

tacitly encouraged some of it. However, one must recognize the possible dangers involved in mob action. It
takes very little to convert a vigorous water fight into
a dangerously mobile anti courageous mob. Fortunately
in recent years riots at Hopkins have not resulted in any
serious injury or destruction, but the potential for such
is great. This is especially true when the inevitable cry
"To Charles Street!" rings out anti the crowd spills off
the campus.
We do not urge complete suppression of boisterous
activities. But we do urge the caution anti forethought
characteristic of the so-called "Hopkins Gentleman."
